meaning: no! exclamation of refusal or rejection.
for a boar to make a certain panting sound when courting a sow.
for rain to drizzle lightly for many hours continuously.
father! term of address to one's father.
base rows of a rice panicle, the least ripe.
ambush s.o. along a route of travel; block a route; wait for s.o. along a route.
bride price demanded by the relatives of the bride.
edible larva of a palm beetle ('kamahung) which infests fleshy palms such as sago, coconut and fishtail palms.
float used by a non-swimmer or one learning to swim; lifeguard or swim instructor who accompanies one learning to swim.
accompany and instruct one learning to swim in the water.
hey! exclamation of disgust, surprise or concern.
moldy smelling, of food that has been stored for a long time.
claim s.t.; claim to be s.t.
allotment or share of property given to a person.
dote on the child of another possessively.
cut off the end of s.t.
welt on the skin left by a whip-like object.
mark s.t. with a welt by a whip-like object.
always, frequently, or regularly do s.t.
take initiative in performing an activity.
drive away an animal, person, or spirit.
white feathered parrot-like bird with a red beak that feeds on matured ears of corn.
slice s.t. into thin but not long pieces, such as tobacco leaves.
dull or lacklustre, of formerly shiny things; dim, of light or eyesight; dark blue, as the sea or the evening sky.
ouch! exclamation of pain, hate, anger, fear, hardship.
pity! exclamation of pity towards s.o. or s.t. pitiful.
beams of a house; restraining fence made of horizontal beams; wall made of horizontal beams.
slash with a diagonal motion, esp. in cutting through s.t. tall and slender like a small tree with one slash.
grunt; for a pig to make an aggressive grunting sound.
accompany s.o. who carries s.t. to that person's destination in order to bring back that s.t.
intrude; try to do s.t. when one does not know how to do it; for s.o. of higher status to intrude into matters concerning those of lower status.
sift; be shaken and jolted while riding a vehicle.
white flourescence emitted by white fungus ('bigtujan) seen at night.
young wood, lighter in color, between the bark and the inner core, of the trunk of certain trees such as Narra.
half-do something; be half-mature, as fruits; be indecicive; reaching only half-way to climax.
right! exclamation of approval to an utterance.
tinea flava; fungal skin disease characterised by white spots.
for food to be half cooked because of wind blowing the flame.
high and prolonged, of voice calling.
be led by s.t. or s.o.
float with the wind or water; obey or follow without question.
woven abaca fibre used as a sieve to separate sago starch from the pulverised sago core.
tree, the bark of which is pounded and used for clothes.
for birds to brood over or for animals or people to care for the young till they are weaned.
for an animal, person, or spirit to roar.
for wood to be infested by wood-borers.
submerge in a body of water; plunge into water or fire; be involved in s.o. else's problem.
drum skin on opposite side of the skin that is hit.
term of address from a woman to a man of same age.
for a person to be covered with body-dirt, indicating a long period of not having taken a bath.
for land to be barren of nutrients.
kind of tall weed that grows along river banks.
spirit that lives in dark swampy places.
stick of firewood which is charred, glowing or burning at one end.
command a dog to pursue game.
spouse! term of address between marriage partners.archaic
nymphomaniac; woman who is sexually promiscious.
for s.o. (usually female) to act promisciously.
fermented sludge-like porridge of cooked rice or cassava used as an ingredient in making wine.Can make one drunk.
invite s.o. to accompany to do s.t.
for a person to burp or belch; for a water container to make a gurgling noise when being filled with water.
for a small child or perhaps an animal like a puppy to whimper.
take s.t. from s.o. by force or wrestle s.t. from s.o.
spirit that causes part of the body to shrivel up (pa'wing).
arthritis; paralysis; general term for diseases which render one unable to walk.
cousin! term of address between cousins.
vine sp.Core pith is used for making bracelets, small baskets and bags. fresh leaves are used for temporary building decoration.
adroit, having an inherent knack for being able to do s.t. well; keen, of eyesight or memory.Often used of tutelary spirits who have a knack for knowing how to treat people so they will get well.
Ata Manobo Negrito or Tala-Ingod, name of an ethnic group.
for thunder or one's stomach to rumble.
hollow, with a small entrance, such as the hollow space sometimes found naturally in an otherwise solid tree; small cave.
for a pig or spirit ('busow) to growl.
green dove bigger than the turtle dove.
brass gong used as musical instrument or in calling familiar spirits.
for a woman to have a miscarriage or abortion.
exclamation to draw attention towards s.t. happening.
smelly solid ear wax from an ear infection; smelly liquid ear wax from an ear infection.
for a birth to be premature or fruit to be harvested too early.
be hardly able or barely able to do s.t.
struggle to do s.t.; struggle to do s.t. with s.t. or s.o.; cause s.o. to be barely able to do s.t.
sturdy in the face of hardship; full of endurance in the midst of hardship.
favorite thing to play with or talk to; favorite child or baby; pet animal; toy; s.t. clung to jealously.
hold or care for s.t. or s.o. tenderly, dearly or jealously.
cause it to rain by beating the river with young coconut palm fronds.
woman! term of address between female friends.
for a female to make female friends.
put arm around s.o.'s shoulder; for a woman to put an arm around another woman's shoulder.
last rows of bananas as they grow on the stalk, closest to the bud, smaller than the rest.
for a pig or person to make a whining noise.
pick on s.o. weaker; for a male to pick on a female.
pacify an angry or drunk person; placate s.o.; appease a spirit.
do s.t. properly or in a comfortable position.
split wood into lumber; unsheath banana or abaca trunk.
take all of s.t. for oneself to the exclusion of others.
be considerate of s.o. having a hard time.
do all of s.t. (especially work), not letting others do it; monopolize.
for a dog to bark at s.t. or s.o. while pursuing it; for a dog to bark.
chip wood or rock into small pieces little by little.
rummage in a container in search of s.t.
be worried, concerned or jittery about s.o. or s.t., almost panicking.
kind of small frog heard especially in rainy season from locations where there is standing water.
eyelid; tender area of skin below the eye.
name of a female spirit.Believed to cause plagues.
be half-awake and drowsy after being awakened from deep sleep, not fully conscious; be suddenly awoken from a deep sleep.
smell a fragrant aroma such as perfume or food.
care for an animal with a view to obtain a share of the offspring.
watch over cooking food or a cooking fire.
feel hot, not due to fever.
feel uneasy; feel hot and humid.
feel hot, not due to fever.
shoulder blade and associated muscles of a person or animal.
cowlick; whorl of hair at the crown of the head.
be adept at performing a certain activity.
water vapor caused by heat from skin or cooking food; steam; vapor.
mother! term of address to one's mother.
father! term of address to one's father.
brother! term of address to an older male.
swear a prohibition upon s.t., prohibiting its utilization by specified people for purposes also specified by the one uttering the declaration in response to a misfortune.
I give up! exclamation of disgust at being unable to obtain s.t. after trying with some effort; not interested! exclamation of rejection or for belittling s.o. or s.t.

tarsier; species of monkey.Nest is either in tree or ground. Jumps like a monkey; eyes like a cat; ears like a human; with big eyes. Form is like a monkey. People say it eats charcoal and when it walks, will not walk forward.
green flying lizard with a hanging throat.
father! term of address to one's father.
father! term of address to one's father.
pitiful! exclamation of pity towards s.t. or s.o. weak or lonely.
mother-in-law or daughter-in-law of a woman.Umayam dialect
obtain the favor of s.o. by doing s.t. for that person; make up after a quarrel or offence; ask for forgiveness.
large dark red ant.Fat and dark red or black; more than half an inch long; has large mandibles that can tear skin; usually nests in palm branches.
tree with edible fruit.Source of drinking water when tapped.
small ant which nests in tree branches.Nests used as bait for fish traps ('bogjas) for catfish ('pantat) and land crabs (yo'sob).
food that triggers a chronic, dormant sickness.
eat s.t. off a bone, seed, utensil, or finger.‘You will become very poor. (Lit: You will put your finger in your mouth (as your only viand).)’
be the cause of trouble or misfortune.
not interested! exclamation of rejection or for belittling s.o. or s.t.Used in rejecting offered positions or offers of marriage, or belittling the one making such an offer.
reddish shrub that grows along river banks.Used as trellis for climbing vegetables. Leaves roasted with banana leaves and used as ointment for treating scabies and other skin diseases.
reddish color of a fighting cock similar to the ana'gasi shrub.
kind of palm with hand shaped leaves.Fan like leaves used as roofing; stem used as flooring and bows for arrows.
reedy grass.Used for weaving mats, bags and hats.
monster.Believed to originate from a dead pregnant woman buried with her child. Attacks only males.
work continuously little by little as it comes along until completed.
bushy plant.Medicinal. Cambium layer (between bark and wood) is soaked in water and drunk as a treatment for cough. Leaf tip is crushed and inhaled, or soaked in water and drunk.
black cicada like insect.Emits a distinctive high pitched sound during dry days in the forest.
kind of soft-wood tree.Has a fragrant flower.
camote tuber that grows some distance from the main plant.
slash with a diagonal motion, esp. in cutting through s.t. tall and slender like a small tree with one slash.
kind of song bird.Perhaps shortwing and/or ruby throat and/or thrush shama and/or redstart. Basic song is a three note high-low-high triad repeated with an increasingly higher pitch.

for child to take refuge while playing a certain game of catch.Only used in reference to a particular children's game of "catch". The "it" stays near a pole (andawan) while the others scatter. The aim of the game is for the others to grab the pole (take refuge, andaw) without being caught by the "it". Anybody caught becomes the next "it".
woman! girl! term of address used by a girl or woman in addressing another female of the same approximate age.
go away; go there, s.w. very far from the speaker.
attend a feast or other gathering where food is served.archaic
go there, s.w. not too far from the speaker.
go there, s.w. moderately far from the speaker.
be cut short in the middle of an activity or climax.
do s.t. neatly; be well groomed.
skin disease characterized by large watery skin eruptions or blisters.
for the body of a person or animal to be completely infected by a disease.
scar left on a person or animal by a rope which has been tied tightly.
for s.o. to have body odor.
for food or chaff to smell burnt.
foul-smelling fishy smell, of improperly dried fish, or vaginal odors.
give me! imperative command to give s.t. to the speaker.
altar where the sacrificial animal is tied and killed.Commonly used for pigs, sometimes for chickens.
come here to the location of the speaker.

altar or religious hut.Made of wood or bamboo. Usually constructed in front of the house where offerings of food, betelnut quid, tobacco, wine, fresh eggs, unpolished rice, candles and incence are placed. Decorated with young coconut fronds.
for the soul of the dead, usually a particular dead person, to harass s.o.
yeeh! exclamation of reluctance, fear, or indifference towards s.o. or s.t.
palm sp.Edible top is recommended for lactating mothers.
scarce, of food, shelter, clothing and other things considered necessary for survival.
hardwood tree used for house posts and fences.
reddish colored, of a fighting cock similar to the color of the inner bark of the a'nislag tree.
female spirit of thunder and lightning.
for the spirit Anit to punish s.o. for breaking a taboo.Anit taboos cover incest and inappropriate behaviour towards certain animals, insects, and reptiles.
hide of an animal that has been skinned.
soft-wood tree that produces peanut-like fruit.
heirloom; precious personal belongings of the dead.
for water to wash s.t. away, as in a flood.
for food to be improperly cooked because the fire underneath the cooking pot was allowed to die down before the food was completely cooked.
cook s.t. slowly over a low fire.
kind of termite with red head and white body.
kind of white bird; Eastern Saurus Crane; heron.
s.t. that whirls around; whirlwind; whirlpool.
kind of frog with long thin legs; person with long thin legs.Frog usually seen on dried banana and other kinds of leaves. Light in color. Leaves behind a little amount of water when it jumps.
small melon about ten inches long and four inches in diameter; honeydew melon.Edible flesh is yellow and slightly sweet.
brown millipede about three centimeters long.Emits flourescent light when touched. Lives under floors.
expose oneself, especially when hiding to avoid being seen or hit by a projectile weapon.
stare blankly into space with the body motionless, as when in deep thought.
heap s.t. over the brim of a container.
kind of medium sized tree.Fruit is used as a glue; also a favorite food of birds. Bark and top is boiled and drunk as a remedy for cough and fever.
praying mantis.Young boys are warned to not go naked below the waist or they may be circumcised ('tul�) by the praying mantis.
guide or lead s.o. s.w.; guide s.o. how to do s.t.
glorious looking or brightly shining, of the moon or stars; glorious looking or beautiful, of a woman.

kind of spirit with big lips.Said to live in places where pandan grows. Mocks the pandan gatherer, asking her questions about what she is going to do with the gathered pandan. If humored with the answers, it laughs and its lips cover the whole face giving the gatherer time to run away.
be angry or slighted when teased; take a joke personally.
edible kind of sweet tuber.Grows as a thorny vine
katydid; green hopping insect with elongated head.
double or place s.t. in multiple layers; commit adultery.
carry s.t., esp. a child, on the waist above the hips.
low fence trap or dam for wild animals or fish.Made of sticks and leaves about a foot high. Funnel shaped. Game or fish are funnelled or guided into the trap by this fence.
kind of hardwood tree.Used as construction material. Sap used as lighting fuel.
raise s.t. with the palm of the hand; support s.o. with help, money, or encouragement.
clods of soil that remain undissolved from eroded lands.
handle of a bladed weapon or tool such as a knife, bolo, or spear.
kind of yam.Both the leaves and tuber are eaten.
recipe of yam leaves cooked in coconut milk.
yoke trap for small game such as monkeys, lizards and civet cats.Tong shaped pieces of wood designed to trap an animal by squeezing a body part such as the neck or limb.
offer betelnut chew to the spirits.
sacred container for betel chew offering.
offering of betel chew.Consists of betel nut, ecmo leaves and lime, together with rice, eggs, tobacco, and wine.
travel en masse for a purpose.

skin disease characterized by firmness of the skin and itching.Medicine for this is to mix hearth ashes, with the juice from the leaves of the ka'tumbae pepper plant, into a paste, and to apply it to the infected area.
taste alkaline or astringent, like unripe banana.
kind of high flying bird, possibly the swallow or the lark.
polish rice or millet by pounding a second time.
for a person to age or mature.
verbal affix in indicate that the action is done by each and every person.
be frightened, esp. for birds to be frightened.
bite off a large portion of s.t.
help s.o. pound s.t., usually rice.
only or just, all of a group or class of things.
only; just; have, do, or be s.t. to the exclusion of everything else.
overburden s.o. with work or problems.
white fever sores in the mouth.Usually affects children.
woman! girl! term of address to a younger female.
darn! exclamation of frustration or disgust as after missing a target or stepping on s.t. dirty.
for a child or young animal to become sickly due to premature weaning.
yuck! exclamation towards s.o. or s.t. ugly, dirty, small or weak.
yuck! exclamation uttered upon failure to reach a certain goal or refusal to do s.t. considered disgusting.
burn s.t. completely so that only ashes remain.

herbal plant with heart-shaped dark red leaves.Leaves are heated over a fire and juice extracted from the leaves and mixed with water as a treatment for cough. Undiluted juice used as ointment for a skin condition (ku'libra).
be harried because of an inability to cope with a great deal of work in a limited amount of time.
wow! exclamation at the sight of s.t. of great size, speed, height, weight or number.
for two or more people to work together performing complementary tasks in a job that requires more than one participant.
ear wax; smelly liquid ear wax from an ear infection.
small fire made using medicinal herbs.
smoke and heat s.o. in a herbal fire.
oh darn! exclamation of frustration or disgust as after missing a target or stepping on s.t. dirty.
oh no! exclamation at the sight of s.t. or s.o. pitiful.
for a place to be isolated and lonely.
mythical person who built a golden house (salim'bae) for Yumabot, a righteous man.
acquire a plant or animal with the purpose of reproducing it.
paddle a boat with an instrument other than an oar or paddle.
for a voice to be loud and prolonged.
call s.o. loudly and prolonged at the top of the voice.
kind of rattan with edible fruit.Fruit is an ingredient of betelnut quid.
forego s.t. (usually food) in order to give it to s.o. else.
for higher ranking people to rankle those of lower status.
be drugged from chewing betel nut quid.
go back and forth or from one to another.Collocations: Food, job, house, man, woman.
before; prior to; s.t. is done before the next thing can occur.
trash or garbage swept into a pile, ready to be burnt.
of a place slightly lower in elevation; small ravine or river where water flows, but which may or may not permanently contain water.
for two or more people to help one another to accomplish a job for each of them; assist mutually.
witch-like person who harassess pregnant women, newborn babies, and sick people; vampire.Usually female.
children's game of hide and seek.The 'it' is the vampire who seeks the other players.
harvest a large quantity of grain.
piece of wood ember glowing at one end, buried in ashes on the firetable, usually not going out for several days.Used to start a fire.
kind of softwood tree used especially in making coffins.Core of trunk is dug out as a coffin. Does not decay readily when buried.

thorny vine with a large yellow tuber root.Tuber is edible when properly prepared by peeling, slicing, covering in ashes, then drying. When dry, it is soaked in the river overnight. The ashes are washed away the next day. It is then ready for cooking. Usually eaten only during famine. Tops are roasted, pounded together with earthworms, and thrown in the river as a fish poison. Fish will surface drugged.
carry s.t. or s.o. on the back; if a basket, the straps are slung on the shoulders.
for animals to mate, the male riding on the back of the female.
soul of a living person which goes around harassing and harming people, usually at night.
medium sized tree with fruit the size of tennis balls.Fruit is a favorite food of hornbills.
of an area populated with many wild pigs.
poor-shot, of a person who cannot hit a target.
young unraveled frond of a palm tree.
small curved knife usually used for splitting betel nut.Also used for slicing betel and ecmo leaf, and for splitting and cleaning rattan.
score or make a line on a surface.
silt left on a riverbank after high water recedes.
medium sized softwood tree that bears small round purple and green edible fruit the size of a marble with four segments.
uproot, yank or pull out s.t. that is quite firmly implanted, such as a post or stick.
tall, sharp bladed grass that grows in swampy places.
place where 'bae-as grass grows.Usually swampy lowlands.
basket like fish trap woven from bamboo strips placed horizontally in the water with the funnel entrance facing downwards.For small fish ('po-it).
longitude; imaginary line stretching north-south, that divides east from west.
young teenage male around ten to twenty years of age.
small melon about ten inches long and four inches in diameter; honeydew melon.Edible flesh is yellow and slightly sweet.

specific rhythm.Some rhythms include the following: bi'naylan 'ritual dance'; mi'nangguyangan 'war dance'; 'binanug 'courtship dance'; pi'nandanggu 'ritual dance'; ba'limb� 'social dance'; 'saut or si'neg 'war dance'; ki'nampilan 'bolo war dance'.
straight double edged dagger with a blade about ten inches long.
dagger shaped peg in the center of a fowl trap where the decoy bird is tied.
meet s.o. at a certain place by arrangement.
misalign s.t. out of symmetry; place s.t. out of its proper quadrilateral, equilateral, or isosceles position.
relationship between parents of a married couple.
black and white color of a kind of chicken or bird.
kind of large rectangular basket carried on the back like a backpack.Made of rattan, usually solid, with large outward facing double doors.
spider lily, a medicinal plant.Leaves are long and thick. Flower is white. Stalk contains juice used for medicine in treatment of 'pasngu sickness or malaria.
large basket for storing rice or corn made from the bark of the a'gahon tree.
sensitive, of a person who can see spirits and other invisible beings; also of a person who easily finds lost, missing or hidden objects; perceptive; clairvoyant.
skull of a person or animal.
rainbow.Believed to be a manifestation of the god of war. At one end of the rainbow is a tortoise, about a fathom long.
for thunder and lightning to occur.
medium sized tree with large leaves and branches like inverted tripods.Bark used for dyeing; pith in the middle of the trunk is soft and foamy; wood easy to split; branches used as chair legs.
for prepared food to spoil or turn rancid.
fence an area to keep out animals which might spoil a crop.
spear trap for catching large animals (e.g. pigs, deer) or people.Consists of a sharpened stake attached to a young sapling which is bent back and acts as a spring.
trap an animal with a 'baetik trap.
type of hard black stone in river beds.
cow peas; bean; string beans; baguio beans.
kind of wine made with honey.
kind of small reddish wasp that makes a mud nest.
stem of the ecmo vine.Used as ingredient of betelnut quid instead of ecmo leaves if there are no leaves.
ritual belt worn by a priest or priestess.Made out of braided cords of 'nit� vine strips and human hair; bundles of dried aromatic herbs, seeds, bark, roots, shells and charms are attached to it.

pandan leaves which have been stripped and are wider (about half inch wide) than the usual size of stripped pandan leaves (about quarter inch wide), so called because it is about the size of a molar.Used for weaving large baskets and mats.
warrior.Refers to a man who has killed many people. He is possessed by a spirit called taeg'busow who incites (pa'maj�) him to kill.
force s.t. pointed downward with stabbing motion; kill an animal with such a motion; pound s.t. into the ground such as a post or stick.
rub back and forth against s.t.
trail left by a person or animal through grass or dirt.
large inedible elephant ear yam plant that grows in swampy places.Used in stopping severe weather by magic, by covering a tree stump with a leaf; sap causes severe itching.
wear a belt.An amulet is sometimes placed in the belt during pregnancy to protect the baby and for easy delivery.
s.t. used for tying or bundling objects together.
young flower of palm trees, especially betelnut.Used as decoration for altars (ang'kawan, 'angkow and 'angkae).
grey shrimp like crustacean about six inches long with medium sized pincers.
for a branch of a tree to snap or break; for s.o. to break off a branch of a tree without tools.
make a ringing noise, as a bell.

for a dove to whinny or make a trilling sound.Adgawan dialectWhen heard in the direction ahead and two to three o'clock or nine to ten o'clock from the perspective of a traveller, it is considered a good omen. If farther back, it is a bad omen.
for a turtle-dove to make a whinnying sound from the direction two to three o'clock or nine to ten o'clock from the perspective of a traveller.Gibong dialectConsidered a good omen.
beat s.o. or an animal severely.
stop! earthquake! exclamation uttered in the hopes of stopping an earthquake.
kind of grass with sharp bladed leaves that grows in big clumps.
type of sand consisting mostly of sand and some plant residue; sandy loam.
break up soil with a sharp pointed stick.

bow and arrow used for hunting small prey such as fish, fowl, monkeys and lizards.Double or triple pronged barbed metal arrowhead is attached to the arrow shaft (daga's�) with a string and is detachable. Arrowhead will be embedded in the prey, while the shaft serves as a float (in water), called pa'taw, or an anchor (on land).
coconut sap (tuba) that is highly fermented but not yet vinegar.Maintained as fermented tuba and not vinegar by constant transfer of container, removing the residue.
of a person who always and only wears g-strings.
jar made of 'tis�, which is harder than clay.Silver in color but darkens as it ages. Used to hold rice wine, sugar cane wine, etc.
sacred porcelain jar with tiger head handles and dragon figures on the body.Used as the seat for an inductee during induction (yug'natan) as a chief or warrior.
wealth of a person as indicated by possessions.
abort journey.Abort a journey when a person or animal in a travelling party sneezes because of the belief that misfortune will befall if the journey continues.
fishtail palm.Top is edible and also a source of tuba ('tunggang). Wood used as flooring. Core used to propagate edible larvae (a'batod).
for a wild pig to eat agricultural crops.
warn or stop s.o. from doing s.t., usually s.t. bad or dangerous.
stop wind, rain, thunder and lightning by magic.Using a ladle for wind and rain; 'tubli roots for lightning and thunder; and a command to stop.
female chief; title of a female tribal leader.
ask permission from s.o. to leave or to do s.t.
kind of wine made by boiling honey with water and adding a kind of rhizome ('yangkuas).
for a supernatural being to cause s.t. to happen, esp. to humans.
whistler; small brown insect eating bird.
the relation of two males, one of which is a brother of the other's wife.
approve or like s.t. that a person does; consider s.t. that a person does right.
for the belly of a person to be constipated.
for a snake to bite s.o.
large kingfisher which nests in steep riverbanks.
kind of tree that bears flowers only during the rainy season.Thought to cause cold-like disease in chickens.
for chickens to suffer from a cold-like disease.
dry and tough, of cooked starches such rice, sweet potato and yams.
corn snack made from grated young corn wrapped in corn sheaths and boiled.
for a pig to be laying on its side tied on the sacrificial table ready to be sacrificed.
for a part of the body such as the eye or the belly to feel uncomfortable, as when having foreign particles under the lower eyelid.
kind of design in weaving, beadwork and tatooing.
armband made of 'nit� vine or brass.
for bananas to have hard, reddish spots, indicating woody flesh.
yellow-orange colored with white spots, of a chicken.
shave hair from the face or head.
transfer residence or objects to another location.
of two possible positions of s.t, to be the wrong way.
turn s.t. over, around, or inside-out.
make an excuse; refuse a request.
tenderloin, muscles stretching along the spine.
large hardwood tree with edible sour fruit.Good for building materials.
wrap a cloth around the body; wrap a cloth around the body unde the arms.
tie tightly so that it is difficult to undo.‘Become easily upset.’
adjectival affix denoting having a pronounced tendency towards the state or action expressed by the root.
tumble, flip or roll over several times.
knot.Traditionally, knots (usually on a rattan strip) were used to keep track of time and activities, much like a calendar.
for potential fruit on a tree to bud in clusters, such as 'bugk� and 'kaepi.
choker worn around the neck made of beads.
sliver or strip off the outer layer of bamboo.
strips or slivers of the outer layer of bamboo.Used in weaving.
knife made out of a sliver of the outer layer of bamboo.Used to cut the umbilical cord or tobacco leaves.
balete tree ; strangler fig.The root of this tree, when pounded, is good for healing broken bones and sprains.
house beam where studs are attached.
peg of a rooster trap (ka'liyas).There are four pegs in one trap.
small black and white insect eating bird with some yellow and rose colored spots.
kind of small freshwater fish about ten inches long.
kind of plant from which cord for sewing nipa is obtained.Outer layer is stripped and made into cords.
give or host a party or special meal in honor of s.o.
medium sized hardwood medicinal tree.Bears violet or pink flowers; dry leaf is used for kidney cure, boil and drink; bark is used for dysentery and other similar diseases, boil and drink.
for a trail to be clear.
cure s.o. from sorcery.Potions or ointments are used as a cure for victims of sorcery such as 'kumitan or 'yumajan.
for a house or field to remain unfinished.
kind of poisonous palm found in the forest.
ambush or wait for s.o. along a path; block or put s.t. across a path.
kind of large and poisonous mushroom.
defend s.o. verbally to s.o. who does not yet know the offense, without stating the offense.
notch steps on a tree or a slope.
chock s.t. to prevent it from rolling; elevate s.t. by placing s.t. under it.
s.t. used as a chock or to elevate s.t.‘Food (Lit. Stomach filler).’
medicinal plant.Used to treat teething, fever and diarrhea, boil and drink. Grows in a clump with stems radiating out at angles from the center.
tie up s.t. or an animal securely in a bundle so that it may be easily carried.
large dugout canoe, usually carved out from a ya'nipg� tree.
spirit altar in the sky.Considered invisible to ordinary people except priests (di'watahan).

hanging altar, a replica of the spirit altar in the sky.Open square or triangular box suspended by strings from the corners connected to a single point on a rope. Figures of rooster crests adorn the corners. Young coconut fronds adorn the sides.
for the sun (or moon) to be in the position of early afternoon; that is, after it has passed directly overhead, about one to two o'clock in the afternoon.archaic
hit s.o. very hard in the back with a stick.
shrub like medicinal plant.Leaves heated until withered and used as a poultice bound around sprains, dislocated bones or broken bones.
for a part of the body to feel numb.
shout in anger; shout expletives; speak loudly in anger.
whistle loudly with fingers in the mouth (to call s.o.).
large hardwood tree usually found with woodpecker holes.Parrots and other birds usually nest in these holes.

bundle of coconut sheath fibres used as an insect repellent when burnt.Made from the sheath of the coconut flower, which is dried and cut into strips, then tied together as a bundle. Burns very slowly, producing smoke. One bundle may last up to two days.
large, of a honeycomb or insect nest.
rub s.t. on the body, esp. ointment.
small community under the jurisdiction of a municipality.
chip away protruding or excess parts of wood with a bolo, making it smooth.
wood which has been smoothed by a bolo.
train a dog to hunt game.By letting a young dog go hunting with old dogs.
medium sized softwood tree.Trunk may be tapped for drinking water. Fruit usually eaten by deer and bu'titok parrakeets. Places where this tree grows are considered fertile.
provided; mark my word; as long as.
watery or pus filled blister, usually caused by abrasion.
lift s.t. from the ground up to the shoulders.

charm like object, usually metal, used to negate evil effects.Must be a personal belonging of the giver. Usually a coin, pin, or other small object. Given by a single young man or woman, or married person who is in an illicit relationship, to a priest or priestess upon entering the house of that priest or priestess. Also given by a woman in labor to the widwife doing the delivery or by the husband of the pregnant woman. And, given by an initiate in a ceremony to the person conducting the ceremony, usually a priest or priestess. This is given to negate evil effects on the receiver, usually illness (or, blindness in the case of a midwife). If it is given by the husband of a pregnant woman to the midwife, it is to negate the effects of his sins on the baby and his wife, and the midwife will rub the object on the belly of his wife. This gift is expected protocol and may be demanded by the receiver if not given. The receiver usually rubs it on his or her own body, usually where there are aches or pains. Some priests might rub the object on their forehead to aid visualization of the cause of an illness during a healing ceremony. A midwife would rub it on her forehead to prevent blindness.
for s.o. to give a personal object to a priest, priestess, midwife, or other such person.
small snare trap usually for birds or sometimes civet cats set on the branch of a tree.
small kind of dugout canoe which seats one.
long net trap for catching wild pigs and deer.About fifty to a hundred meters long and a meter and a half high. Placed across game trails. Game is chased into the net with the help of dogs.
undeveloped egg found inside a bird.
find or retrieve s.t. that was hidden by oneself or, if hidden by s.o. else, which the retriever knows the location of; go or return s.w. to retrieve s.t. hidden.
specific hiding place for objects, usually regularly used.
apply a poultice to a boil or other skin disease.
design in weaving, beadmaking, and tattooing following the carapace design of the turtle.
large red bushy plant with small round fruit.Fruit used as pellets for childrens' bamboo air-guns.
trap spring usually made out of a long slender shaft of wood or sapling.Traps which use this spring include 'baetik, bat'hajan, 'bayod, and 'lit-ag.
for s.t. long and slender to bend like a trap spring.
kind of rattan used for tying and weaving of baskets and fish traps.
kind of softwood tree used in the manufacture of matches, toothpicks and spatulas.
face of a person or animal.
shaman, priest, priestess or spirit medium.
kind of rhythm; kind of dance.
dance performed by Manobo from near the Agusan-Bukidnon boundary.
noose trap for small animals.Noose is suspended from poles crossed in an A-shape. This kind of trap can catch rats, lizards, wild chickens, rats, reptiles.
reciprocate good or evil; reply; revenge.
fluent and articulate, of a speaker and discussion leader.
apitong, kind of hardwood tree used in construction.Sap is used for lighting fuel and for sealing boat hulls.
bluish grey color, of chicken.Color of a certain dove ('bayud).
kind of vine which grows along riverbanks.Stem is pounded, mixed with water, and a bubbly juice is extracted and used as a shampoo or soap.

long climbing bamboo about an inch in diameter with prickly segments about ten inches long.Segments contain much water which is used for drinking when in the forest. Segments are split lengthwise and made into rim clamps when weaving baskets.
clean off the soft unused core of rattan strips by scraping with a blade.
pandanus palm.The leaves are used in weaving mats, hats and baskets.

medium sized softwood tree.Flowers once a year around February. Two events are associated with the flowering of this tree. One is that chickens get sick with mucus in the throat ('pukdow/'bakan). The other is that wild boars caught at this time are smelly.
flowering season of the bayu'yow tree, usually February when it gets cold.
wave s.t. back and forth, such as a fire-torch, palm frond or handkerchief.
throw s.t. with one or two hands.
mane of a pig (usually only wild boars have manes) or horse; pig's hair.Pig's mane can be made into a necklace or bracelet.
tree and fruit that looks like mango, but green with a fibrous rounded seed.
durian seed with the fruit still sticking to it.
boat made from a carved tree trunk.
for the back of a person or animal to arch backward or curve concavely, such as a pregnant woman or pig, or a horse with many riders.
metal tool used in harvesting rice.
harvest rice by cutting each head individually.
beater; reed; flat piece of wood used to compress the weft threads in the waist loom.
harpoon driven by a rubber band.
fish with a harpoon under water using goggles.
tease s.o. to the point of tears or anger.
of a person or spirit who persistently teases people.
kind of lizard that jumps from tree to tree with ribs extended like wings.
edible fungus that grows on dead plants during the wet season.Emits a flourescent light ('aemag) at night.
slash or stab s.o. with a weapon unexpectedly, without warning.
roast s.t. by placing it beside the fire, usually root crops.
get a cramp in a muscle.

If you are a man, the husband of your wife's sister is your bi'las. The wife of your wife's brother is NOT your bi'las. If you are a woman, you should NOT call either the wife or the husband of your husband's brother or sister bi'las. The above definition may be the traditional view. Some men call the wife of their wife's brother bi'las. Some women call the wife or husband of their husband's brother or sister bi'las. Some people consider these latter usages incorrect usage of the word bi'las, noting that 'idas is the right term.
dirt that forms in the eye.
rub eye dirt out of the eye.
greedy, of s.o. who eats a lot all the time.
separate gold dust from sand by panning.
round, concave wooden disk for panning gold.
hinder s.o. from voicing, speaking or singing.archaic
kind of design in cloth weaving.
drinking party with dancing and singing.Party prepared for close friends. Often the host mixes some rice and viand and gives a handful of this to his guest.
kind of rice with large white grains, husk is also white.
kind of green banana eaten cooked when unripe or ripe, or raw when ripe.
bend the gape of a fish hook wider or narrower; for a hook to pull and straighten while fishing.
hare-lipped, of one whose upper lip is split; be shy, as if one is hare-lipped.
adze with the blade at an angle to the handle, looks like a heavy hoe.Used to carve dugout canoes and coffins.
bamboo or wooden carving of a crocodile.
mutilate flesh, skin or ears by tearing.Ears of slaves used to be notched as a mark of identification. Now only applied to domestic animals. There is an ant (ami'minsae) which mutilates flesh.
kind of small kingfisher.Four times smaller than a 'saegsag.

type of plait like weave design for rattan or vines.For rattan, this weave is usually constructed from a single strand. This rattan weave is commonly used for ferrules of tools and weapons. Vine weave is made into bracelets, armbands and legbands for men.
medium sized kind of round short basket woven out of pandan leaves.Reinforced with rattan strips and sealed with tabun'tabun seeds. Usually used to contain personal belongings.

for the spokesman of the potential bridegroom to propose marriage to the father of the potential bride; for the various spokesmen in a marriage proposal to discuss the marriage.The family of the potential bridegroom will hire a spokesman to propose marriage to the father of the potential bride. The father of the potential bride may or may not hire a spokesman to continue discussions. The first approach is for consent for the marriage. If consent is given, in essence, the subsequent discussions will be about the bride-price which the family of the potential groom will give to the family of the potential bride. The first approach and all subsequent discussion is called bi'saya. The discussions are often full of idiomatic expressions.
visit with s.o. at his or her house.
put clothes on; saddle a horse.
for an official to investigate s.o.
for a boil or internal organ to burst.
kind of medium sized medicinal softwood tree which grows along riverbanks.Cambium layer scraped, boiled and drunk as medicine for cough and fever. Wood is good for carving.
kind of medium sized softwood tree which grows along riverbanks.
carry s.t. such that it dangles.
disease of the eye characterised by a white growth in the eye; white growth in the eye which can obstruct vision.
for s.o. to have a white growth in the pupil of the eye.Often treated in early stages by dripping the sap of the sigun'dina plant onto the growth.
leave a long line or trail of s.t.
string used in hanging mosquito nets.
pit; deep hole in the ground.
kind of design in embroidery, beadwork and tatooing.
stab downward with a spear or bolo to kill a sacrificial pig.
hole in the side of a drum.
separate from s.o. or s.t. formerly highly valued (e.g. spouse, house).
larva of an insect which eats the flesh of young coconuts.
roe; cluster of fish eggs found in the belly of a fish; fish ovaries.
invert an eyelid to expose the red inner part of the eyelid which looks like fish ovaries.Kind of funny face made at people who have had a mild accident.
kind of fine yellow rice that looks like roe.
of a fish with full ovaries.
kind of sweet made from root crops or glutinous rice mixed with coconut milk and wrapped in banana leaves and boiled.
for a woman or female mammal to be pregnant, especially if it is evident from appearance.
intense, of rain, wind, flood, famine, fever and sickness.
for s.o. to get a relapse of a sickness; for s.o. to get sick after recovering from a sickness; for a woman who has just given birth to get sick, usually from bleeding.

kind of funnel shaped woven fish trap about two feet long and a foot in diameter.Usually for catching catfish ('pantat) when baited with termites and ants wrapped in banana leaves. Placed facing downstream.
kind of harwood tree used medicinally.Cambium layer is scraped and juice extracted for treating white fever sores in mouth.
for the sun or moon to reach its zenith.
twist s.t. very hard in order to break it apart.In the story of Mangondo, a small but strong wire was used to bind Mangondo after his subjects bound him with strong rattan in vain.

cotton like fluff obtained from the outer portion of the heart of fishtail or cabonegro palms.Used as kindling in starting fires with flint and steel ('titilan). Prepared as kindling by thorough drying and mixing with ash from pandan leaves.
for an animal to spring a trap; for a trap to spring; attack s.o. by surprise.
pound grain such as rice or corn into powder.
rice or corn which is first dry fried, finely pounded, then mixed with sugar cane syrup, and wrapped in dried banana leaves.Common trail food which lasts a long time.
wrap s.t. for roasting, usually fish or meat with banana or a'nahaw palm leaves.
gather clothes or similar materials which have been hung out to dry.
give s.t. as an appeasement to an offended one so that the offender can be released from liability.
be satisfied or pleased with s.o.
pound fiber so that it can be woven.
do s.t. forcefully (as putting s.t. down); speak hurtfully.
stammer, esp. due to shyness or fear; hesitate to speak, esp. when afraid to tell the truth.

kind of small black nocturnal bird.Much smaller than a crow and believed to be possessed by evil spirits to bother people in the evening, especially during moonlit nights, making a scary sound (ngit... ngit... ngit...).
break; destroy; abort a fetus intentionally; miscarry.
clear newly harvested rice field; clear a newly harvested field of leftover growth.
reinforce a woven pandan container with rattan or nito.
river debris left in a pile.
name of a malevolent spirit who creates famine.
beat a certain kind of rhythm.
pound rice the first time through.
coconut shell with small opening used as a cup.
spread out s.t. which can open flat, but not flowers.
experience or discover the absence of s.o. or s.t.
be tired of doing s.t. or waiting.
bamboo or wooden carving of a crocodile.
kind of design in embroidery, beadwork and tattooing.
kind of funnel shaped woven fish trap about six feet long and more than a foot in diameter.Much larger than 'bogjas.
for s.o. to act disgruntled, murmuring and stomping the feet, but still obeying instructions.
for the direction of the whinnying sound of the turtle-dove to come from the direction just above the forehead directly ahead from the perspective of a traveller.Considered a bad omen.
cover on the ridge of a roof.
kind of vine with broad leaves.Vine used for tying.
spear that is prized by the owner.Usually used only during war.
horn made from large shells or long tubes.Formerly used for signalling.
honeybee larvae still in the comb or extracted from the comb; honeycomb with larvae still in the comb.
pole; unit of s.t. long such as logs, bamboo or sugar cane.
pulverized lime used for betelnut quid.
guard an area to chase away animals.
scarecrow; one who watches the rice field from birds.
for bananas to have hard, reddish spots, indicating woody flesh.
for work to be left unfinished.
cleanse and soften cloth, usually by soaking in lime water.
pay a fine for dishonoring a woman.
oh no! exclamation of disgust at s.o. leaving s.o. or s.t. alone, or for not doing s.t. good.
clear a burnt field of debris.
branches and other debris left behind in a field after burning.
foster child, one who is cared for by s.o. other than the parents or immediate family (can be applied to animals).
ecmo vine.Leaf is used for betelnut quid.
kind of design in cloth weaving and embroidery.
roasted mudfish with scales on, mouth and tail bound together.
defile, render unfit for sacred use, especially of sacred knives.
foam at the mouth as during an epileptic fit.
uproot a tree or pole, toppling it so that it lies on its side.
lansones flower.Looks like a woven ferrule.
prolific, of a hen, laying eggs soon after hatching the previous brood.
drive away things that come in a group, such as bees or enemies.
airy, fluffy or loose in texture, such as soil, cooked rice or a cake.
large basket for storing rice or corn made from the bark of the a'gahon tree.
early dawn, when first light appears.
for bees to leave the hive after larvae have metamorphosed and honey has been consumed.Occurs seasonally during the dry season around May.
boring insects such as woodborers or weevils.
flee suddenly from s.t. or s.o.
node of a tree, bamboo or cane; knot.
swiftly, of chasing or being chased.
sheath s.t. cylindrical in leaves for roasting over coals, such as a fish or durian flesh.
spread out or unfold s.t. flat; for a flower to bloom.
fatal, of venoms, poisons and evil spirits.
open wide s.t. slit like such as eye, mouth, thighs, female genitals.
exclamation at s.o. indicating that that person got the deserved punishment, accompanied with the action of pulling down one's lower eyelid at the person.
pull down one's lower eyelid at s.o., saying "bu'likat"; rejoice at s.o.'s misfortune.
for a woman to sit exposing her genitals.
seal a crack or hole with a viscous substance.
pump used to pump air or water.
rolls of fat around the waist or under the chin; paunch.
acquire an animal or plant for breeding or propagating.
tassel like flower of plants such as corn, sugar cane or 'tigbow grass.
tang of a blade such as a bolo or spear, the part that fits into the handle.
cook s.t. in a fire, wrapped in leaves and placed on the coals.
s.t. cooked in a fire wrapped in leaves.
hit an obstacle in the way.

piece of woven rattan or 'nit� vine which acts as a cover, and regulator or shaker of a lime container ('tangtang), a piece of betelnut quid equipment.Some women place sewing needles inside the 'bungkae to prevent the needles from rusting.
decorative cover for a 'kambue basket woven from rattan strips and attached to the basket itself (not removeable).
medium sized tree bearing pods containing two or three large round, flat seeds.Children make spinning toys from the seeds. Seed is also used as the flywheel in the cotton spinning process.
small owl-like bird with big eyes.
reach the end or boundary of a place, such as a road, river or mountain top.
boundary; goal; end of the line.
kind of long green banana which turns lighter green when ripe.Eaten raw.
kind of softwood tree with long pods and winged seeds.Wood used for carving religious artifacts.
overwork to the point of death.archaic
for a tree or bamboo plant to fall with the cut end into the ground first, when cut, before the rest of the tree falls.Dangerous to the one who cuts.
place where the cut end of a tree hits the ground if it falls cut end first.‘horizon; place where the sky meets the earth at the edge of the world’‘foot of a mountain’
any very bright heavenly body other than the sun, moon, or smaller stars, including the morning/evening star, shooting stars and comets.
meet a friend after a long time without seeing one another.
of a man with a pot belly.
of a man with a pot belly.
kind of dark violet colored rice.Two kinds: Glutinous and non-glutinous.
violet colored, the color of 'buntud rice.
throw a spear or similar long thin object with one hand.
stab with a pointed weapon with an intention to kill; kill by stabbing; use a spear to stab with both hands.
grow thin from suppressed grief, sorrow, or anger.
for s.t. to be covered with moss.
for s.o. to decide or commit to do s.t.
commit to do s.t. in vain.
for s.o. to stand s.o. else up, not showing at a prearranged meeting.
call down a curse from a supernatural power.
pour s.t. that is dry, grainy and heavy, such as rice, corn or sand.
for rice panicles to come out of the stem, a stage in rice growth.
urinary affliction characterised by constant passing of urine.
for s.o. to be through in doing s.t., considering oneself finished, the task not necessarily being completed.
give overexaggeratedly to s.o., usually so that that person will suffer from too much (such as by vomitting if too much food is given); pretend to give when one's intention is not to give.
bow used to shoot an arrow.
for s.o. to be punished supernaturally when going against s.o. considered an elder, such as parents, or when wasting food.
for chickens to fight, usually two roosters.
male of certain animals, esp. dogs.May sometimes be applied to males of cats, carabaos, goats, horses and civet cats.
uproot a plant or post with upward movement.
small cyst-like growth on skin, not dark.
hard reddish spots on camote or avocado, a kind of plant disease.
kind of small green parrot with white beak.Usually found eating the fruit of the a'mison or ba'sikung trees.
for a dog to fight another dog (sometimes applied to cats).
for dogs to fight one another.
kind of small yellow-green bird with a yellow breast.Called tailor bird because its nest looks like two leaves sewn together.
kind of large blackish ant with white markings about three quarters of an inch long.Has a painful bite which tears flesh. Can build their nests on the ground but usually in hanging plants.
bloated dead fish found floating on the water.
for a fish, person or animal to be dead, bloated and floating.
buy s.t. (usually dogs) by barter.Can be partially by money.
take out or reveal s.t. stored or hidden, including secrets; extract body parts such as eyes or intestines.
large lump on the skin, usually the size of half a tennis ball, a kind of disease.
refuse to accept s.t. because one feels that what is offered is not enough, or because it was not given when one first asked for it.
swing or rock s.o. in a hammock.
coconut kernel, the soft white spongy part in the center of the coconut from which the shoot grows.
stomach of the 'gingow fish, quite large.Used as a container for salted mudfish eggs. Hung over the firetable.
dark red background with white spots, of the color of a chicken, usually roosters.
for a shaman to perform a ritual healing of s.o.
rebuke s.o. for repaying evil for good.
be partially blind, in either one or both eyes.
bamboo commonly used for walling, arrows and spears.
kind of design in cloth weaving and embroidery.
hill, one side of which is a cliff beside a river.Can sometimes be a hill surrounded by water with no other hills beside it.
small kind of banana about three inches long and an inch in diameter.
for s.o. to be brash, brazen, shameless or impudent.
airy, fluffy or loose in texture, such as soil, cooked rice or a cake.
hit s.t. or s.o. with s.t. somewhat flexible (such as a broom or tree branch) with a downward stroke.For example, when driving away snakes from the trail while travelling at night
hit s.o. hard in the upper back with the fist or palm in an overhand swing, usually hurting the lungs as a result.
for hair, leaves or fur to become thick.
lap up, slurp or lick liquid with the tongue.
gizzard.Children are not allowed to eat gizzards in the belief that if they do, they will not want to move unless s.o. hits them in the back ('dabu).
thumping sound of hitting s.t. hollow.
ground runner of a plant such as yam.
for a plant to crawl or put out ground runners.
for a snake, worm or similar creature to crawl along the ground.
rustling noise in the grass, as of s.o. hurrying through.
make a loud banging noise repeatedly.

rave or talk irrationally.Temporary state of extreme mental excitement marked by restlessness, confused speech and hallucinations. It sometimes occurs during fever as in certain diseases, in some forms of insanity.
laugh shrilly.The way female spirits laugh.
implicate s.o., as in a crime.
nectar and pollen collected by bees, placed in the honeycomb, to be turned into honey.
steep, rocky cliff beside a river.
of s.t. that is quickly consumed.
woman! term of address for a woman the same age or younger.
of a person who is happy and makes a lot of jokes.
for a group of people to be happy, talking, joking, laughing among themselves.
kind of tree that bears fruit eaten by the grey dove ('bayud).
rice straw or stalk left after harvesting.
hurry somewhere to help because of an urgent crisis.
bamboo shaft of a fish arrow ('bagyoy) which floats.
for the water level to rise.
shake off or shake out s.t. powdery.
bump, bang or crash into s.t.
trample on s.t. or s.o. or step on it many times.
economize by using a resource carefully; be thrifty.
work less hard to preserve a weak body.
for a bird of prey to catch by swooping down on the prey.
snatch s.t. and bring it toward oneself.
blanket woven out of abaca fiber.Sometimes used as a hammock, sometimes as a skirt.
for a dying person to groan.
fins of a fish: dorsal, pectoral, pelvic, anal; not caudal fin, which is 'ikug (tail).
name of a malevolent female spirit.Said to cause hunger by bringing about poor harvests. A female person who is thought to be the cause of misfortune may be accusingly called Da'gow.
for s.o. to experience evil because of s.o. female.
lightly slap the shoulder or hip of s.o. or s.t.
bamboo tube used as water container.
for a path to be smooth, clean and free of obstructions.
source or headwater of a river.
hissing sound of falling rain approaching from the distance.
for the rain to make a hissing sound as it approaches, falling in the distance.
for s.t. relatively soft and perhaps hollow, such as the chest of a person, to make a thudding sound when hit.
stay away for a long time.
for s.o. to perform actions while sleeping, such as talking and walking; babble incoherently while semi-conscious.
new trail made by a person or animal travelling through a grassy place.
pole for carrying a heavy load by two or more people, at least one on each end.
carry a load on a pole with another person.
wash clothes, esp. by pounding on a rock or log.
great, of expectations, importance, number or size.
for a cloud to briefly cover the sun.

edible winged white ant-like insect considered newly metamorphosed.Appears during light rain, landing on the river. Collected by placing bamboo booms across the river. Dry fried and eaten as a delicacy.
strike buttress root of a tree with a piece of wood as a form of signalling.Usually to signal that a trap has caught s.t. or that there is imminent danger.
travel on the slope of a mountain; for tears to roll down the face; for the sun to cross the sky in the south, during October, Novermber and December, not directly overhead.
kind of rhizome with dark red edible fruit which are molar shaped.
female spirit said to cause promiscuity or flirtatious behaviour in women.
for a woman to be flirtatious or promiscious.
have no knowledge about a matter.
thick fungal saliva which comes out of the mouth of a very sick person or corpse of a person who died of a respiratory disease.
fungal disease affecting the respiratory system, esp. the mouth.
large adult male deer; stag; buck.
grope about, as in the dark.
sticky mixture of mud and dead leaves; clay; clayey soil, not good for growing things.
cry; prolonged wailing, not real loud.archaic
kind of small shrub with hairy leaves used medicinally.Cambium layer is scraped and placed over a boil to draw out pus.
touch or cover s.t. or s.o. with an outstretched palm.
hit s.t. or s.o. with the side of a bolo.
lay s.t. flat on a body briefly for medicinal purpose.
burn oneself by touching s.t. hot.
for a skin disease to be aggravated.
oh no! exclamation of dismay when one's work fails.
large river turtle that burrows under mud.Lays eggs in sand bars.
for wild animals to eat ripe fruit, usually fallen ripe fruit.
of a tree which bears fruit that is eaten by wild animals; of a place which has trees which bear fruit which are eaten by wild animals.
put s.t. on a chopping block or anvil.
begin a rice harvesting season by harvesting a little portion.Usually in preparation for the 'taephag ritual.
warm a body part or clothes near a fire.
for nipples to get erect, esp. when pregnant.
for s.o. to lay flat on the back on the ground after falling.
bluish soil embedded with mollusk shells which is very slippery and slimy when wet, and solidifies into a very hard block when dry.
smell of singed hair or feathers.
span; unit of measure from the tip of the thumb to the tip of the little finger.
brown lobster-like freshwater crustacean about six inches long with light blue stripes on the side of the head.
press a person or animal against a wall, tree or similar object to prevent escape.
push a handful of food into the mouth with the hand, as if wiping the mouth with the palm and fingers.People feed one another in this manner during feasts, esp. during traditional weddings.
small hairlike thorns of bamboo and other plants that are itchy to the touch.
for s.t. to be scratchy in texture like the hairlike thorns of bamboo, causing itchiness.
medium sized softwood tree with a thorny stem and yellow spotted green leaves that bear red flowers.
splat; for s.t. watery and dirty to make a splatting sound when hitting s.t. solid, such as the sound of carabao dung hitting the ground or mud hitting the face.
itchy dust such as that found in rice grains and mungo beans.
for birds to be attracted to eat the fruit of a certain tree.
fruiting tree which attracts feeding birds.
hurry and repeatedly do s.t. without stopping.archaic

talk animatedly and rhythmically in rhyming speech with vigorous hand actions and pounding, a loud voice, and repeatedly half standing up and dropping forcefully to the seat.Common speech style of older men in conference.
put s.t. on a chopping block or anvil.
prize given to the winner in an organised fight.
for a lot of people to be lying around dead or sick.
for s.t. to bounce back to where it came from when the original intention was for it to penetrate.
dish food out and serve it.
for s.o. to lie prostrate, face down; place a container with the opening down.
for fish to be affected by poison, surfacing.
for s.t. to be as small as a grain of millet.
hard center as small as a grain of millet in half-cooked rice.
for a girl to be around the age of first menstruation.
for a snake to catch prey.
for a fish to bite the bait.
for s.o. to be disappointed at s.o. else.archaic
for s.o. to lay down with the face up; place an object down with the concave side facing up.
feel the effects of s.t. such as a typhoon or storm.Usually in reference to indirect effects of the typhoon. You wouldn't say this if you vere actually in the path of the typhoon.
be happy; rejoice ; make happy noises.
appease the spirits by means of an offering.
attractive to men, of a female around the ages of ten to thirty, not neccesarily beautiful; pretty; with a pleasing personality.
thud; for s.t. or s.o. to make a thudding sound when hitting the ground after falling from a height.
wail, esp. because of a death.
for s.t. or s.o. slippery to slip out from inside s.t. or from the grasp, such as a baby from the womb or a fish from the hands.
crash; for s.t. large and heavy, such as a large tree, to make a crashing sound when it hits the ground or an object after falling from a height.
above; higher place relative to the speaker.
make s.t. last a long time.
be careful in a situation where s.t. can be easily broken or lost, or where one may be hurt.
edge of s.t.; foot of a mountain.
for s.t. to reach the edge of s.t.
kind of dance in which the dancer mimics a woman taking a bath.
dark, as in the darkness of night.
opposite side of a geographical feature, such as a river or road.

new moon; one day in the lunar month considered after the day of the last moon and the day before the new moon is sighted; the day there is 'no moon' in the sky.Rattan, bamboo, and nipa are gathered on this day in the belief that it will not be attacked by borers.
voice or formally file a complaint against s.o.
dart the tongue in and out of the mouth.
be careful in avoiding, as in avoiding offense in dealing with others, in avoiding offense to the spirits, in avoiding certain foods.
slice up rather solid objects into thin slices, such as papaya, onion and carrots, but not meat.
shake one's head, perhaps in disagreement.
rock one's head from side to side.
rest one's head limply on the shoulder.
for a projectile to lightly graze an object, not penetrating.
dislocate or fracture a bone such that it sticks out.
pronounce a curse on s.o. to the effect that that person's tongue will fall out.
tutelary spirit.Human like spirit that selects a favorite mortal as their medium of communication.
to haul the harvest to the granary.
large rice basket made out of pandan leaves.Placed in the middle of a field when harvesting. Harvesters fill it from their small harvesting baskets. When it is full, it is brought up to the granary.
there, middle distance from the speaker; sometimes said or written to or concerning s.o. who is still there.
walk with a swagger, swinging the shoulders back and forth.
for a house, tree, or similar object to shake back and forth rapidly, as in an earthquake.
dip s.t. into a container of s.t. else, such as sugar, paint, salt or vinegar.
for a snake to strike with its head raised.
position s.t. or s.o. close to s.t. or s.o. else.
kind of tall grass about five feet tall with triangular stems and sharp edges.Bears flower; produces fruit which small birds come to eat.
place where much dogo'hit grass grows.
throw s.t. at s.t. or s.o.
for the rain to start falling.
for insects and pests which come in groups such as locusts and rats to appear in large numbers.
for s.o. to beach a boat or raft onto the shore from the water.
crawl on the belly like a snake or worm.
become healed; do s.t. well or good.
for s.t. to be the best.
for s.t. to be for the benefit of s.o.
pound or hammer s.t. with a blunt instrument.
for a substance to adhere to another substance.
burnt food stuck at the bottom of a pot.
for a chicken (or duck) to be sick from the chicken flu disease, not moving much and having mucus in the throat.Often occurs during the rainy season.
kind of small white-breasted greenish-black bird that eats insects.Said to be named because it always looks downward.
bear hatred or grudge against s.o.
resolve to do s.t. as the outcome of a meeting.
kind of small, edible freshwater eel.
for rain to fall steadily for a long time.
for s.t. to come into violent contact with s.t. else or a place.
for s.t. to be hit by s.t. else.
for s.o. to press down on s.t.
for a person to be subjected to a bad bird omen.
armspan; unit of measure from fingertip to fingertip with the arms outstretched in opposite directions.
spit out s.t. solid or somewhat dry forcefully.
for s.o. to smash the head of s.o. else into a wall or similar object.
travel or look for s.t. outside at night.

fish poison.Made by first chopping up earthworms. Then patting the chopped earthworms with the leaves of the 'hagupit tree. The worms are then mixed with the crushed roasted tops of the 'baay plant. Only the 'poit fish is affected by this poison.
point on the bottom of a basket.
silky fibers that surround the seeds of a kapok tree.Fibers are often used for stuffing pillows and mattresses.
tell a joke or tease s.o. in fun.
of s.o. who is fond of telling jokes.
still in the process of doing s.t. even though much time has passed.
for a person to be muscular.
nest made of leaves and grass by a sow for her litter.
add difficulty and problems to s.o. who already has problems.
kind of women's dance.Rhythm is provided by bells worn on anklets.
pierce or stab s.t. with a sharp instrument such as a knife.
for milk to flow out of the breast.
cough forcefully (whooping) with a forced inspiration at the end, usually bowing the head while coughing.
for the sky to be overcast.
set fire to s.t. combustible by putting a flame to it.Traditionally in reference to burning a field for clearing.
bumpy or lumpy, of a surface that is thought to be ideally or prototypically level, such as a road or table top.
for a projectile to lightly graze an object, not penetrating.
go on an expedition to recapture a kidnapped woman or to collect by force the bride price from the parents of the kidnapper.
for the uterus to contract before childbirth.According to common belief, the unborn child causes the uterus to contract.
bamboo or wooden stick about a meter long, flat and tapered at one end, used to scrape off the singed hair and skin of an animal.
scrape off the singed hair and skin of an animal in the midst of singing it.

for a female to begin menstruation; for a female to be in the early stage of fertility and not yet reproduce.(Disagreement exists on whether this can apply to all females including people, or only female animals.)
young female at the early stage of fertility.
fried and pounded ka'tumbae chili peppers mixed with salt.
original rice stalk (not the secondary shoots).
end rows of a rice panicle, ripest.
having a protruding upper jaw or recessive lower jaw.
come to served food to eat.
for a pig to root and dig in the soil with its snout.
snout of a pig; upper lip of a person.
beat s.o. with fists or club.archaic
burn s.o. or an animal with the glowing embers at the end of a piece of wood.
for s.t. or s.o. to be lured into a trap.
decorative tubular brass anklet containing iron balls which rattle.Worn by women, esp. when dancing.
for a boat to land or anchor.
slither like a snake; creep like a vine.

for s.o., usually a stranger, to disturb an activity by virtue of that person's presence, so that the activity is unsuccessful.Includes activities such as fishing with poison or some rituals. The belief is that the stranger is an evil spirit or s.o. sent by an evil spirit. In the case of fishing, the stranger is suspected of making the poison ineffective.
turmeric, a yellow-orange rhizome.Used in dying, as medicine to treat swelling or open wounds, and as food seasoning.
stand in the front of a boat or raft to pole and watch for obstacles.
no! exclamation of disagreement or defense.
for liquid to seep into a place.
place where liquid seeps into the ground.
bound; be between two things or places.
exclamation uttered when referring to s.t. unfortunate.
saplings used as poles for construction.

be cursed by an impersonal or personal supernatural force as a result of certain kinds of bad behaviour.‘A curse makes no noise (in coming).’Kinds of bad behavior that can trigger such curse include disrespect to elders in one's family; theft; murder; adultery; oppressing the innocent.
be accidentally cut by a sharp instrument or grass.
for the direction of the whinnying sound of the turtle-dove to come from the direction directly behind from the perspective of a traveller.Considered a bad omen.
spread s.t. apart with some effort.
for an entire household or barrio to go s.w. together for a purpose.
surely not! exclamation of doubt over what s.o. says.
for ribs to protrude due to leanness.
remove with the finger an object from the throat that is a source of choking.
strip of cleared area made around the farm to prevent wild animals from destroying crops.
press an animal or person against a post or tree.
dismember; remove an extremity such as an arm, leg or wing from the body.
try to do s.t. one is incapable of doing.
mill or grind rice, corn or mongo beans.
ascend by foot; go to one's farm.
hold s.t. soft and slimy such as mud or feces.
ceremonially take the bride home to the house of the bridegroom, accompanied by a female relative of the bride.
grip of a spear made from a coil of brass wires.
large kind of hardwood tree good for construction material.Bark is medicinal and also used to flavor palm wine.
pull s.o.'s hair, esp. when fighting.
even; even as; such as; indeed.
freeboard of a boat from the waterline.
not fully loaded, of a boat.
cut a buttress root, usu. either to get a piece to use as a handle or to remove the stump.
for a person outside of a dispute to take sides with one of the participants of a dispute.
knock over a wall or other tall, broad object.
tie up the opening of a container, usu. baskets.
rope for tying limbs of animal or person.
tie limbs of animal or person.
cut the root of a large tree.
enough for survival, of food or medicine.

subterranean stream.Found near lakes. Located by observing crab holes and listening with the ear to the ground for the sound of moving water. Holes are made over the stream and traps or hooks set for catfish, which are often found in such streams.
oar fastened to the side of the boat.
for s.t. (usu. a weapon) to be embedded in the flesh.
for s.t. to be piled improperly.
grope for s.t. under water with a hand or pole without touching the bottom.
clamp s.t. or s.o. tightly in the mouth, as a dog or snake would.
better-off than s.o. else, of a person.
trunk of a fishtail, coconut or sago palm tree.Edible larvae (a'batod) of the kama'hung beetle found here.
funnel entrance of a fish trap which allows fish to enter and prevents them from escaping.
override s.o.'s rights by dominating them.
rope inserted in the nose of animal used to lead it.
carry s.o. or s.t. on the waist, above the hips (usually a baby); hold s.t. in the lap.

main living area of a house; floor with joists and girders.Most houses are built up off the ground, with the main parts being the pillars (or, in some cases, large tree or stump on which a house is built), main living area up off the ground, and roof area. This main living area, the level of the house where the floor is constructed along with its supporting girders ('sakbat) and joists ('gagae) is called gi'baejan.

figure of an iguana cut from the skin of the back of a slaughtered pig as an offering to the spirit Taegbusuw; design in weaving, bead-making or tattooing following the color and scale pattern of the iguana.
cut narrow strips of s.t., usually pandan leaves for weaving.
tsk! exclamation of annoyance, impatience, frustration, disgust or fear, usually expressed at s.o. (the source of annoyance, etc...).
experience pain in the upper abdomen.
main body of a house, excluding the porch and kitchen.
home or house in the hinterland.
drum with skin top and hollow wooden body.
wriggle, of a ball of worms.
feel cramped because of too many things in an enclosed area.
large freshwater fish.Stomach of this fish is used to store salted mudfish eggs.
breath; feeling; seat of the emotions.
fibrous sheath at the base of palm trees.
step on s.t.; thresh by treading.
yikes! exclamation of fear or disgust.
runt or smallest piglet in a litter, usually the last born.
snap; break s.t. long and slender.
unusually small, of a gall bladder.Of significance in a sacrificed animal.
kind of tree with edible fruit.

oxbow meander in a river with a cutoff channel through the neck of the oxbow; cutoff oxbow meander; island in a river surrounded by an oxbow meander and cutoff channel; silted up sections of an oxbow meander between the oxbow lake and the cutoff channel through the neck of the oxbow; oxbow meander in a river; oxbow lake; dried up oxbow lake.
cut or chop a log or tree.
for clothes to be shredded into rags while being worn.
yikes! exclamation of fear or disgust.

good, of the bird omen.The belief is that when the cry of a turtledove is heard in the one to three o'clock and nine to eleven o'clock position in the direction the traveller is moving, that is a good omen. The implication is that he will have a successful journey and a good feast ahead of him.
chop down a tree; demolish a structure.
be the rice planting season that occurs during the rainy season around September to January.
that's right! exclamation of agreement or approval at the statement of s.o. else.
for a tree or wooden structure to decay.
cut young corn off from the cob.
for an idea to linger in one's mind.
gently hold private parts, especially the breasts or nipples of a woman.
suck or hold s.t. in the mouth without chewing.
gently squeeze and hold the breasts or nipples of a woman;
be able to manage or cope with a job.
be able to manage or deal with s.o.
for brittle objects to crack or break.
tie two or more things together, such as wall to beam.
snap; break s.t. long and slender.
sensation of prickles on the skin from perspiration and the heat of the sun.
cut string, vine, or similar long stringy objects with a slicing motion.
be unconscious due to a blow.
fall, of ripe fruit from a tree.
breathless, from hard exercise, holding the breath, or even hunger.
hold the breath in hunger, in fainting or for no reason.
for some reason to cause s.o. to hold the breathe in sadness or in fainting.
make a fire by rubbing bamboo sticks together with a sawing motion.
for a threatening situation to finish off a person.
cut s.t. such as a fish or snake with a slicing motion.
cut or slice of a fish or snake.
creases in the skin, esp. of a fat baby or the inside of the hand and fingers.
measure of one joint of a finger.
small paddle used in rowing or steering a boat.
grope with the hands looking for s.t. underwater.
for s.t. to make a rustling sound, such as leaves in the wind, or dried copra, dried rice, or dried corn when poured or shifted.
kind of small, brown, insect eating bird.
digging stick sharpened at one end.
make a big hole in the earth, such as a gold mine.
for a shaman to search supernaturally by singing continuously.Search is usually for a diagnosis or cure for a sickness.
for one's hair to stand on end.
slit or pierce the throat (neck arteries) of a person or animal.
pull, drag or tow s.t. or s.o.
for s.o. to drag s.t. (such as several children) behind in addition to a full load (perhaps also of children) being carried on the person, such as on the shoulders, the back, and the waist.

be pulled away, esp. a harvest, by spirits; have a bad harvest due to improper practice of rituals.The belief is that if the harvest ritual ('taephag) is not properly observed, a poor harvest may result.
be encumbered or uncomfortable, usually due to an awkward or bulky load.
for s.t. to become loose, such as a tied rope or packed grain.
loose, of tied rope or packed grain; crumbly texture, of food.
break s.t. up into tiny pieces.
dishevel or tangle hair, rope, etc.
for the rim of a container or the side of a boat to be broken along the top edge.
midrib of a leaf such as a coconut frond.
remove midrib of a leaf such as a coconut frond.
beat s.o. severely in the upper torso with fist or club.
thump; sound of the impact of the above kind of blow.
exterminate or kill a person; erase a person from the face of the earth.
chop or cut up protruding branches of fallen or felled trees as preparation for burning a field.
forcefully cut s.t., esp. thick underbrush.
arouse a certain feeling as of fear, anger, or love; start the flow of milk.
for a fever to emerge from inside the body.This is seen as a sign that the patient will recover.
for a rash to appear on the skin.
swelling or aching of the abdomen; swelling of a dead body.
dry season, usually from March to May; drought.
huh? expression of incredulity, questioning or surprise.
intense wind and rain storm of short duration with lightning and thunder.
south-west monsoon season, usually from June to August.
stand by an exit or doorway, ready to go out.
for feet to be infected by a disease characterised by small red spots and itchiness.Said to be caused by wading in standing muddy water.
try to persuade s.o. to do or believe s.t.
belt, string or cloth tied around the waist, usually holding the bolo sheath.archaic
be physically afflicted by evil spirits, by falling sick.
flatten and smoothen leaves to prepare them for weaving.Usually of ba'yuy or ana'hiwan leaves. Often done by running a leaf of the 'hagupit tree along the ba'yuy leaf.
watch in the night for enemies or wild animals.
place from which to watch for the enemy or wild animals.
be angry due to inconvenience.For example, if a husband comes home from work and the wife is not around and no food is prepared, or if one has a lot of work to do and more work arrives.
for s.t. or s.o. to be an inconvenience.
feel hot inside from fever or eating certain foods.
sour-bitter; descriptive of the taste of certain foods such as citrus rind and burnt rice.
slack, of a rope like object.
slacken or lengthen a strap-like object.
kind of medium sized softwood tree that grows on flat ground and bears large bunches of edible fruit.Good for firewood.
kind of strong vine that grows well in moist places.Used for tying. Tops are eaten as a vegetable.
snore; for a cat to purr.
low flat ground characterised by tall grass and low trees.
good, peaceful, well-made, of places and things.
for people or animals to stampede.
yellow-bell; kind of vine bearing yellow bell-shaped flowers and used medicinally.
kind of plant with sandpaper like leaves.
kind of large venomous cobra with a yellow belly and black back.
have plenty of room; become roomy; fit loosely.
hold s.t. up to show it to s.o.
for the heat of the sun to diminish.
double handful; measuring unit, esp. for grain, of two hands cupped together.
scoop s.t. with the hands cupped together.
kind of black ant often seen carrying food, esp. rice.
for a large mass or number of objects to be removed, spilled or poured from a container.
offer cooked food to the spirits.
name of a spirit, the goddess of rice and other grain.
okay! exclamation to agree, warn or scare.
come! Imperative expressed to small ones, usually young children.
low curb attached to a structure to keep s.t. in or out, such as on the edge of a bed.
genuine or pure, of precious metals, antiques, character.
cut or slash using a diagonal downward motion.
knead or work s.t. with the fingers.
