kind of small flying insect that gathers around food and fruit.
forbid! exclamation that one says towards another who has cursed one to counteract the curse.
might be cursed; exclamation towards one who has been cursed.
suffer hardship because of another's misdeed.
warrior with the lowest rank.Refers to a man who has killed one or two people.
kind of medium sized strong softwood tree.Cambium layer is medicinal.
quickly consumable, esp. of stored food.
shiny and dark segmented worm about eight inches long.Lives underground; makes a shrill noise at night.
crave s.t. one has to do without.archaic
sacrifice to a spirit called Hanggunganan after a successful hunt.
name of a spirit to which a hunter sacrifices after catching a pig.
foothold, step or notch cut in a tree trunk or steep hill.
cut steps into a tree trunk or steep hill.
non-members of a family around a household.
be happy due to meeting a loved one.
bite or gnaw at s.t. fibrous.
cover a surface with s.t. before placing s.t. on it.
dump or stuff things into a container.
lay blame on s.o. for another's offense.
extreme, of drought, depth, heat, darkness, brightness or similar events.
arrange a series of items or processes into a nice order.
arrange warp threads on the loom.
feint a stabbing or hitting motion at s.o., but not actually stabbing or hitting the person.
feel hungry or not completely satisfied even if eating; crave for variety in eating, usually of sick people and lactating mothers.
for a roof to be nearly flat.
accuse s.o. falsely; slander; lay blame on s.o.
for s.t. such as wind to flatten plants.
kind of small, black, biting ant.
for these small, black ants to bite.
far side, away from the crowd.
be at the far side, away from the crowd.
pause s.w. in the middle of a journey.
ferry s.o. or s.t. across a river.
rub s.t. on the body with the fingers.
fishing line, usually with hook attached; kite string.
short or taut, of rope like object; short, of time.
shorten or tighten a strap-like object; shorten one's time s.w.‘Impatient.’
hit s.t. hard with an object.
white mite.Often infests a nest after the eggs have hatched.
trim grass, cutting off only a small amount; skim off the top layer of grain in a sack if that layer is bad.
stroke or caress with the palm of the hand.
for flying animals such as birds to land, perch or roost.
apply s.t. by rubbing into a surface.
slip out from grip, as of a limb from a noose or a snake from its skin.
apply heat to and massage an area of the skin.
for a male person to have no covering below the waist.
for pants or skirt to sag or hang loosely below the waist.
take or bring s.t. or s.o. somewhere or to s.o.
remove s.t. from a cooking fire.
piece of wood used as a seat in a canoe.
place pieces of wood across the beam in a canoe to be used as seats.
for a male person to publicly expose the penis without covering below the waist.
unload or get off a vehicle or boat.
retrieve s.t. that was given to another or thrown away.
nick s.t. or s.o. with the tip of a bolo.
let s.t. down by rope, hanging.
offer s.t. to a spirit or deity.
for light, sound or heat to fade or diminish.
for a dead body to stink due to decomposition.
gather nectar from flowers, of bees and butterflies.
calm down, of anger, wind or boiling water.
for people or messages to miss each other unknowingly because they were enroute to each other's place; for people to miss each other when one arrives just after another leaves.
pout; be on the verge of crying.
touch-me-not, kind of weed that closes its leaves when touched.
walk with a swaggering motion, swinging the upper torso from side to side.
swear to the truth of s.t.
apply s.t. viscous on a small area.
choke on food or feel that food is stuck in the throat.
retract or pull back from s.t.
conduct a certain kind of ritual to counteract a plague of disease.Spirits appeased in this ritual are Yu'mud and Ali'mogkat. Offerings are placed on a raft which is left to float downriver.
shore of a sea or lake; riverbank.
chance or opportunity to do s.t.
body-dirt around neck or under arms.
sore which develops along body creases.
be disappointed at s.o., usually because of being let down; have hurt feelings; resent s.o.
shrub that has edible bitter branch tips which are roasted.
sway or move together in one direction, as of a rice field in the wind.
surprise; for s.t. to happen unexpectedly or suddenly.
kind of disease characterized by sudden death.
remove dry leaves from standing plants such as sugar cane or corn.
drop off to sleep; fall asleep.
disturb, molest or touch s.t. or s.o.
till and weed a field using a bolo, burying rice seeds.In shifting cultivation only. Done after seed is sown.
kind of herb used to treat stomach pain.
stone used to rub dirt from the body.
rub dirt from the body with a stone or towel with water.
for a bird to brood on eggs.
bird that is brooding on eggs.
for the level of s.t. in a container to subside or settle.
settle down in a living situation.‘Feel relaxed.’
raw or not fully cooked, of food; unripe, of fruit or vegetables.
thread; bubbles streaming on the river.
for pigs and chickens to call a mate; for fowl to be in heat.
for female animals to be in heat.

jinx s.o. by speaking in jest using names of big animals or extreme weather terms, jinxing s.o. who is hunting.May be done on purpose to jinx s.o.'s hunting trip. Big animals might scare away smaller ones. Bad weather might occur.
settle down in a living situation.‘Feel relaxed.’
gathering, usually for a good purpose.
for rice grains to be filled, a stage in rice growth.
separate the useless from the good.
prepare early or ahead of time.
warm oneself at a heat source.
for a moderately long period of time to pass.
for a plan to fail to materialize.
anoint the head with a liquid such as oil.
rest the chin in the hand.
repeatedly perform an activity that has proven pleasureable.
carpenter; worker; metal or wood carver.
mark or scar left on s.t. from being tied tightly.
who, used as an interrogative pronoun in direct and indirect questions; anyone; anybody.
have hurt feelings by actions or words of s.o.
keep s.t. in a safe place.
keep or put away scattered things in their proper place.
be close together; be similar; be side by side.
for people or messages to miss each other unknowingly because they were enroute to each other's place; for people to miss each other when one arrives just after another leaves.archaic
cut s.t. with a slicing motion.
drive away or out; shake out.
for s.t. cloth like which is hanging to fall, drop, or be pulled down.
decrease the heat of a cooking fire.
one who is firm in intentions and feelings.
for swarms or clouds of s.t. to land on s.t. else, such as fog and locusts.
for a tree or house to shake rapidly.

totem animal representing the body of a person, the owner.The animal, usually a chicken or pig, is made into a totem in a ritual, often a healing ritual. Said spirit or spirits causing the sickness are given the animal to harm, rather than the body of that person. That healed person is charged with caring for the animal totem, until the animal dies a natural death or is sacrificed and replaced with a younger living animal.
keep for one's own use things meant to be passed on to others.
lover, one with whom one has extra-marital relations.
for rice panicles to be empty of grain before harvesting.
clean intestines of a butchered animal.
lose potency, of wine or medicine.
swell, of s.o.'s body or part of a body.
have complete array of some resource such as money, intelligence, clothes, food or kindness.
for animals to learn to avoid danger from experience or observation.
for sunshine to be dimmed by thick overcast clouds.
shelter from the rain or the heat of the sun.
serves you right! exclamation of rejoicing at s.o.'s misfortune, accompanied with the action of pulling down one's lower eyelid at the person.
first catch ever of a hunting dog, hunter, or trap.Must be eaten in the house of the hunter, or owner of the dog or trap.
purify spiritually sin (sa�), curses ('sump�), or taboos (pa'lihon), often ritually.
pull out s.t. long from a hole, pile or bunch.
move up and down, of soil.Indicates muddy ground beneath. Some plants may grow above.
swan maiden; name of a mythical person.
feel lazy or disinclined to do s.t.
for a group to attack or voraciously eat a victim.
as usual; reply to a greeting.
cook bundles of rice wrapped in leaves in bamboo tube over fire.
for small ripe fruit to fall from a tree.
eager to fight, of an animal such as a carabao, dog or fighting cock.
forge or smith articles out of metal.
make up a story or lie.
for two or more people to help one another in work; help mutually.

foretell the future using the swing omen.One will sit with the knees up, or squat, and lean the back against the wall. A piece of string is held at both ends with the hands resting on the knees. A small piece of metal or burnt wood is suspended on the string. The suspended object is consulted about the future and is requested to swing or to stop swinging in response to questions about the future. Movement or stopping of the object is attributed to the spirit who owns the object. The object may be threatened if it does not respond to the questions. For example, one may threaten to burn the piece of wood.

feast offering for the dead.Participants partake of this feast to cut off relationship with the dead person. At the end of this feast, a winnowing basket is filled with the favorite food of the deceased and carried into the center of the house of the deceased by those who carried the coffin. Others will be standing aside. At a signal, the tray is tossed upwards and the carriers rush aside for fear that the food might touch them. The belief is that if that food touches them, bad fortune would come upon them.
